Award.AwardTitle: The Physics of the Smallest Stars and the Planets That Orbit Them
Award.AbstractNarration:
Elisabeth Newton is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a program of research and education at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Newton will study M dwarf stars using data from the Kepler space telescope and new ground-based observations with the Infrared Telescope Facility (IRTF). An M dwarf star is the smallest, most common type of star in the Galaxy. A detailed understanding of M dwarfs is important in its own right, but also because they are perhaps the best places to discover Earth-like planets: the smaller size of the star enhances the signal from an orbiting planet. Equipped with this detailed understanding, Newton will investigate planetary systems around M dwarfs. She will also develop and teach an introductory astronomy course for the Boston University Prison Education Program (BUPEP), with the goal of increasing the mathematical skills, quantitative reasoning, and scientific literacy of inmates in preparation for life outside prison.

Newton will undertake a multi-pronged observational study of M dwarfs, with a focus on evolutionary trends in stellar and planet populations. The program will consist of (1) using photometry from Kepler surveys to measure rotation periods for field M dwarfs and analyze their angular momentum evolution; and (2) a new, extensive campaign with the IRTF to study magnetic field strengths in cool dwarfs. Newton will target M dwarfs with measured rotation periods to investigate the relation between magnetism and rotation, and M and K dwarfs with measured radii to test whether magnetism can be responsible for the observed radius inflation. Finally, Newton will use information on the masses, metallicities, and ages of low-mass M dwarf planet-hosts to investigate the origins of multi-planet systems in compact orbits. As part of her education plan, Newton will develop and teach an introductory astronomy course, which will be the first science course offered to inmates through BUPEP, and which will serve as the foundation for a sustainable astronomy curriculum within the program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Both stars and planets change over time. Stars spin down and become magnetically active. Planetary orbits are impacted by dynamics, and planetary atmospheres by erosion. How and why do stars and their planets produce the populations we observe around mature stars?

This award has led to key contributions to understanding stellar and planetary evolution. New spin rates were measured for M dwarfs (red dwarfs, the smallest and lowest mass type of star) in the southern hemisphere, a region of the sky not yet surveyed for this. This represented a significant contribution of new periods to the literature. These measurements found an abundance of slowly spinning stars, demonstrating that, while M dwarfs remain rapidly spinning and magnetically active for in some cases billions of years, they ultimately reach rotation periods of around 150 days.

Combining rotation rates with measurements of magnetism in these stars, it was demonstrated that there is a close relationship between spin and magnetism in all types of M dwarfs. Unexpectedly, this relationship is very similar to what is seen for more massive stars, which have long been expected to have a different way of generating their magnetic fields than massive stars. Further work on this topic was begun during the course of this program, which is currently under analysis.

Considering the impact of stellar magnetism and other features on the evolution of planets, two young planets were studied in detail. An intriguing young planet, K2-25b, was probed for the presence of additional companions, but none were found. A new young planet, DS Tuc Ab, was discovered. Both of these planets orbit bright stars and can therefore be studied in detail. Thus the award lays the groundwork for many future investigations into these planets.

The PI traveled to conduct observations and to attend conferences to present the work. The PI led three publications and contributed to numerous others.

This award supported the development and teaching of a new introductory astronomy course, taught at a medium security prison. Students gained quantitative skills that can help prepare them for life outside the prison.

This award also supported three undergraduate women in embarking on their first research experiences. The students learned about astronomical measurements, stars, and exoplanets, and gained exposure to the scientific process. Two students attended a scientific conference.
